Award.AwardTitle: U.S.-China Planning Visit: Collaborative Research on Computational Intelligence Systems in Renewable Energy Engineering Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a planning visit to the Control Science and Engineering Department at Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST) in China. Participants in the trip will include Professors Nian Zhang, Esther Ososanya, and Wagdy Mahmoud of the Electrical and Control Engineering Department at the University of the District of Columbia (UDC) together with two students. The purpose of the trip is to develop a collaborative research project on nonlinear forecasting methods based on computational intelligence techniques, particularly neural networks. The theoretical strength of the Chinese partners will complement the experimental studies at UDC. Initial applications of new techniques of forecasting, particularly using neural networks and fuzzy logic, would involve renewable energy systems based on solar radiation and wind.

In promoting research collaboration among the participants, this planning visit will lead to new and more reliable forecasting techniques that can contribute to more efficient and economical alternative energy systems. The participation of students in an international program will broaden their personal and professional perspectives. UDC is primarily an undergraduate institution whose student population consists largely of underrepresented minorities. Opportunities for such students to engage in the international linkage should make the study of engineering more appealing to them. Also, the fact that two of the UDC faculty involved here are female engineers should have a positive impact on female students in particular.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major research and educational outcomes for the U.S.-China Planning Visit: Collaborative Research on Computational Intelligence Systems in Renewable Energy Engineering Applications grant were as a result of the June 2011 visit between the  PI Nian Ashlee Zhang, co-PIs Esther Ososanya, Wagdy Mahmoud, and an undergraduate in the Electrical and Computer Engineering at University of the District of Columbia (UDC) and the faculty at the Control Science and Engineering (CSE) Department at the Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST) in China.

The main objective of the trip was for the PI and Co-PIs to meet with the professors of the Huazhong University of Science and Technology to initiate research collaborations. During the visit, the PI's and faculty members from HUST:

1)      Visited the research labs at HUST to see how they use online learning techniques to teach the neural networks method of statistical analysis to a variety of complex facilities and equipment;

2)      Discussed how to apply the advanced neural networks analysis techniques developed by HUST to renewable energy data generated at the University of the District of Columbia ;

3)      Planned future collaborative research between the universities centered around the solar radiation/wind speed forecasting methodologies that are now underway;

4)      Initialized the development of international grant proposals to support the collaboration between HUST and UDC;

5)      UDC presented data generated by the solar photovoltaic and wind-turbine combination electrical generation system housed at the Zero Energy Visitor Center [1] at UDC to the students at the Huazhong University of Science and Technology;

6)      The undergraduate student from UDC was trained on how to use the neural networks toolbox, and how to develop and implement computational intelligence methods on time series prediction problem;

7)      Disseminated the UDC’s MSEE program brochure to the students at HUST; and,

8)      Analyzed the solar radiation/wind speed data from UDC's model Zero Energy Visitor Center, through the application of the neural network techniques and time series prediction techniques to assess their applicability to predicting the reliability of renewable energy generation. The results have been published in five papers

 

References

[1] Research Title: “Solar Cells Efficiency Capture: Theory, Modeling, and Simulation” PI: Dr. Samuel Lakeou, Co-PIs: Dr. Esther T. Ososanya and Dr. Wagdy Mahmoud, 2007/2008 NSF SGER grant, ECCS-0749319, $65,000.
